sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Acne (Severe); Adjunct: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours
  • Actinomycotic infection, second-line agent when penicillin is contraindicated: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours; continue for at least 24-48 hours after symptoms and fever subside
  • Amebic infection, To amebicides; Adjunct - Intestinal infectious disease, To amebicides; Adjunct: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours; continue for at least 24-48 hours after symptoms and fever subside
  • Anthrax, second-line agent when penicillin is contraindicated: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours. Continue for at least 24-48 hours after symptoms and fever subside (all Group A beta-hemolytic streptococci should be treated for at least 10 days)
  • Bacterial infectious disease, Enterobacter aerogenes, Escherichia coli, Acinetobacter species, Shigella species: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours; continue for at least 24-48 hours after symptoms and fever subside
  • Bartonellosis: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours; continue for at least 24-48 hours after symptoms and fever subside)
  • Brucellosis: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours with streptomycin; continue for at least 24-48 hours after symptoms and fever subside
  • Chancroid: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours
  • Cholera: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours; continue for at least 24-48 hours after symptoms and fever subside
  • Clostridial infection, second-line agent when penicillin is contraindicated: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours; continue for at least 24-48 hours after symptoms and fever subside
  • Disease caused by rickettsiae: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours
  • Gonorrhea, second-line agent when penicillin is contraindicated: 600 mg ORALLY initially, then 300 mg every 12 hours for 4 days (3 grams total)
  • Granuloma inguinale: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours; continue for at least 24-48 hours after symptoms and fever subside
  • Inclusion conjunctivitis: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours; continue for at least 24-48 hours after symptoms and fever subside
  • Infection by Campylobacter fetus: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours; continue for at least 24-48 hours after symptoms and fever subside
  • Listeriosis, second-line agent when penicillin is contraindicated: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours; continue for at least 24-48 hours after symptoms and fever subside
  • Louse-borne relapsing fever: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours; continue for at least 24-48 hours after symptoms and fever subside
  • Lymphogranuloma venereum: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours; continue for at least 24-48 hours after symptoms and fever subside
  • Mycoplasma pneumonia: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours; continue for at least 24-48 hours after symptoms and fever subside
  • Nongonococcal urethritis: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours; continue for at least 24-48 hours after symptoms and fever subside
  • Plague: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours; continue for at least 24-48 hours after symptoms and fever subside
  • Psittacosis: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours; continue for at least 24-48 hours after symptoms and fever subside
  • Q fever: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours; continue for at least 24-48 hours after symptoms and fever subside
  • Respiratory tract infection: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours; continue for at least 24-48 hours after symptoms and fever subside
  • Staphylococcal infection of skin, second-line therapy: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours; continue for at least 24-48 hours after symptoms and fever subside
  • Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion: 600-1200 mg/day ORALLY
  • Syphilis, second-line agent when penicillin is contraindicated: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours; continue for at least 24-48 hours after symptoms and fever subside
  • Trachoma: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours; continue for at least 24-48 hours after symptoms and fever subside
  • Tularemia: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours; continue for at least 24-48 hours after symptoms and fever subside
  • Upper respiratory infection, Streptococcus pneumoniae: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours; continue for at least 24-48 hours after symptoms and fever subside (all Group A beta-hemolytic streptococci should be treated for at least 10 days)
  • Urinary tract infectious disease: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours; continue for at least 24-48 hours after symptoms and fever subside
  • Vincent's infection, second-line agent when penicillin is contraindicated: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours; continue for at least 24-48 hours after symptoms and fever subside
  • Yaws, second-line agent when penicillin is contraindicated: 150 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 300 mg ORALLY every 12 hours; continue for at least 24-48 hours after symptoms and fever subside

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• Not recommended for children under 8 yrs
  • Acne (Severe); Adjunct: 7 to 13 mg/kg/day ORALLY divided into 2-4 doses; MAX of 600 mg/day
  • Actinomycotic infection, second-line agent when penicillin is contraindicated: 6.6-13.2 mg/kg/day ORALLY divided into 2-4 doses
  • Amebic infection, To amebicides; Adjunct - Intestinal infectious disease, To amebicides; Adjunct: 6.6-13.2 mg/kg/day ORALLY divided into 2-4 doses

  • Chancroid: 6.6-13.2 mg/kg/day ORALLY divided into 2-4 doses
  • Cholera: 7 to 13 mg/kg/day ORALLY divided into 2-4 doses; MAX of 600 mg/day

  • Nongonococcal urethritis: 7 to 13 mg/kg/day ORALLY divided into 2-4 doses; MAX of 600 mg/day

  • Psittacosis: 6.6-13.2 mg/kg/day ORALLY divided into 2-4 doses

  • Respiratory tract infection: 6.6-13.2 mg/kg/day ORALLY divided into 2-4 doses
  • Staphylococcal infection of skin, second-line therapy: 7 to 13 mg/kg/day ORALLY divided into 2-4 doses; MAX of 600 mg/day
  • Syphilis, second-line agent when penicillin is contraindicated: 6.6-13.2 mg/kg/day ORALLY divided into 2-4 doses

  • Upper respiratory infection, Streptococcus pneumoniae: 6.6-13.2 mg/kg/day ORALLY divided into 2-4 doses
  • Urinary tract infectious disease: over 8 years, 7 to 13 mg/kg/day ORALLY divided into 2-4 doses; MAX of 600 mg/day
  • Vincent's infection, second-line agent when penicillin is contraindicated: 6.6-13.2 mg/kg/day ORALLY divided into 2-4 doses
  • Yaws, second-line agent when penicillin is contraindicated: 6.6-13.2 mg/kg/day ORALLY divided into 2-4 doses

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment- reduce dose or increase dosing interval
  • liver impairment-reduce dose or increase dosing interval

sub.mono:

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: hypersensitivity to tetracyclines or any component of the product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• children younger than 8 years; risk for permanent discoloration of the teeth; avoid use
  • Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea, including mild diarrhea to fatal colitis, has been reported
  • long-term therapy; nephrogenic, dose-dependent, and reversible diabetes insipidus syndrome (polyuria, polydipsia, and weakness) has occurred
  • hepatic impairment; dose reduction recommended
  • photosensitivity may occur; discontinue use if erythema occurs
  • pregnancy; risk of fetal harm; avoid use
  • pseudotumor cerebri (benign intracranial hypertension) has occurred
  • renal impairment; may cause systemic drug accumulation and possible liver toxicity; dose reduction necessary; monitoring recommended with prolonged therapy

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Demeclocycline: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

sub.title: Major
sub.mono:
• Amoxicillin (probable)
  • Ampicillin (probable)
  • Bacampicillin (probable)
  • Bexarotene (theoretical)
  • Cloxacillin (probable)
  • Dicloxacillin (probable)
  • Digoxin (theoretical)
  • Etretinate (theoretical)
  • Isotretinoin (theoretical)
  • Methicillin (probable)
  • Nafcillin (probable)
  • Oxacillin (probable)
  • Penicillin G (probable)
  • Penicillin G Benzathine (probable)
  • Penicillin G Procaine (probable)
  • Penicillin V (probable)
  • Piperacillin (probable)
  • Pivampicillin (probable)
  • Sultamicillin (probable)
  • Temocillin (probable)
  • Tretinoin (theoretical)

  • Magnesium Trisilicate (probable)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Demeclocycline hydrochloride is a bacteriostatic antibiotic agent that inhibits protein synthesis against a wide range of gram-negative and gram-positive microorganisms.

0.title: Absorption
0.mono:
• Oral: time to peak concentration, about 4 h
  • Effect of food: dairy products reduces absorption by more than 50%

3.title: Excretion
3.mono:
• Biliary
  • Fecal: 13% to 46% as active drug
  • Renal: 44%
  • Dialyzable: no (hemodialysis); no (peritoneal dialysis)

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • antacids containing aluminum, calcium, or magnesium impair absorption
  • iron-containing preparations impair absorption
  • take 1 hour before or 2 hours after a meal
  • take with adequate amounts of fluids to reduce the risk of esophageal irritation and ulceration

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• gonorrhea: serologic test for syphilis at time of diagnosis and follow-up test for syphilis after 3 months
  • venereal diseases with suspected coexistent syphilis: dark-field examination before treatment is begun and monthly blood serology for at least 4 months
  • periodic laboratory evaluation of organ systems, including hematopoietic, renal, and hepatic in long term-therapy

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
TETRACYCLINES
USES: Tetracyclines are used in the treatment of a wide variety of gram-negative and gram-positive infections. PHARMACOLOGY: Tetracyclines are bacteriostatic and exert their antimicrobial effects by inhibition of protein synthesis. EPIDEMIOLOGY: Exposure is relatively common. However, severe toxicity is not observed. Anaphylaxis can develop during therapeutic use in some individuals. OVERDOSE: Severe toxicity following acute overdosage is unlikely. MILD TO MODERATE TOXICITY: Nausea and vomiting are common following overdose. SEVERE TOXICITY: Hypersensitivity reactions can develop with therapy in the form of various skin rashes along with more severe reactions including angioedema and anaphylaxis. ADVERSE EFFECTS: COMMON: Nausea and vomiting with therapeutic use. Epigastric burning and ulceration may also occur. Skin hyperpigmentation may develop. Renal dysfunction, including elevated BUN, may occur due to the antianabolic activity of tetracyclines. DEMECLOCYCLINE: A diabetes insipidus syndrome has been reported following demeclocycline. CHRONIC EFFECTS: Chronic ingestion of therapeutic doses can cause discoloration and enamel defects in the teeth of the fetus if used after the 12th week of pregnancy or in infants during the first 6 to 8 months of life.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
TETRACYCLINES
  • Support: MANAGEMENT OF MILD TO MODERATE TOXICITY: Tetracyclines generally have a low order of toxicity. Treatment is symptomatic and supportive. For significant vomiting and/or diarrhea, treat dehydration with IV fluids as necessary. MANAGEMENT OF SEVERE TOXICITY: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive. Monitor renal function following a large overdose. ANAPHYLAXIS: Mild to moderate allergic reactions may be treated with antihistamines with or without inhaled beta adrenergic agonists, corticosteroids or epinephrine. Diphenhydramine: ADULT: 50 mg orally, IV, or IM initially, then 25 to 50 mg orally every 4 to 6 hours for 24 to 72 hours. CHILD: 1.25 mg/kg orally, IV, or IM initially, then 5 mg/kg/day orally in 4 divided doses for 24 to 72 hours. Treatment of severe anaphylaxis also includes oxygen supplementation, aggressive airway management, epinephrine, ECG monitoring, and IV fluids.
  • Decontamination: PREHOSPITAL: Severe toxicity is unlikely, gastrointestinal decontamination is generally NOT required. DILUTION: Tetracycline and doxycycline have been implicated in causing esophageal ulcerations when taken therapeutically with minimal amounts of fluids. Immediately dilute with 4 to 8 ounces (120 to 240 mL) of water or milk (not to exceed 4 ounces or 120 mL in a child). HOSPITAL: Tetracyclines are generally of a low order of toxicity. In most cases, gastrointestinal decontamination will not be required. Antacids may be useful in managing gastric irritation.
  • Airway management: Airway support is unlikely to be necessary following mild to moderate exposure; airway management may be necessary in patients that develop severe anaphylaxis.
  • Antidote: None.
  • Monitoring of patient: No specific lab work (CBC, electrolyte, urinalysis) is needed unless otherwise clinically indicated following a minor exposure. Monitor renal function after very large ingestions or in patients with baseline impaired renal function. Plasma tetracycline concentrations are not clinically useful.
  • Enhanced elimination procedure: Hemodialysis and hemoperfusion are unlikely to be of value with these agents because of their high degree of protein binding. Tetracycline is not dialyzable.
  • Patient disposition: HOME CRITERIA: An asymptomatic child taking an inadvertent 1 to 2 tablets can likely be monitored at home, or an asymptomatic adult taking an inadvertent extra dose can be safely managed at home. Tetracycline and doxycycline have been implicated in causing esophageal ulcerations when taken therapeutically with minimal amounts of fluids. Immediately dilute with 4 to 8 ounces (120 to 240 milliliters) of water or milk (not to exceed 4 ounces or 120 milliliters in a child). OBSERVATION CRITERIA: Patients with a deliberate self-harm ingestion should be evaluated in a healthcare facility and monitored until symptoms resolve. Obtain a baseline CBC and renal function following a significant exposure. Patients may be discharged to home once symptoms have resolved and laboratory studies are within normal limits. ADMISSION CRITERIA: Patients experiencing severe or persistent anaphylactic symptoms should be admitted for further monitoring and treatment as indicated. CONSULT CRITERIA: Contact a medical toxicologist or Poison Center for assistance in managing patients with severe toxicity or in whom the diagnosis is unclear. Patients with a deliberate self-harm ingestion should be evaluated by a mental health specialist.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
TETRACYCLINES
TOXICITY: The minimal toxic or lethal dose is not well established in the literature. Severe toxicity following acute tetracycline overdose is unlikely. THERAPEUTIC DOSE: ADULT: ORAL: Tetracycline: 1 to 2 g/day; Doxycycline: 100 to 200 mg/day (up to 400 mg/day for some indications); Minocycline: 200 mg/day; Demeclocycline: 600 mg/day. PEDIATRIC: Tetracycline (older than 8 years): 25 to 50 mg/kg/day, up to 3 g/day; Demeclocycline: 6.6 to 13.2 mg/kg/day; max 600 mg/day; Doxycycline (older than 8 years): 4 to 8 mg/kg/day, usually up to 200 mg/day (up to 400 mg/day for some indications); Minocycline (older than 8 years): 4 mg/kg initial dose, then 2 mg/kg every 12 hours.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Patient should avoid activities requiring mental alertness or visual clarity until drug effects are realized, as drug may cause dizziness, light-headedness, or blurred vision.
  • Drug may cause photosensitivity. Advise patient to use sunscreen and avoid tanning beds.
  • This drug may decrease effectiveness of oral contraceptives with concurrent use. Recommend additional form of birth control.
  • Advise caregivers that drug may permanently discolor teeth in children younger than 8 years of age.
  • This drug may cause nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of skin erythema, dysphagia, glossitis, or hepatotoxicity.
  • Tell patient to take drug 1 h before or 2 h after a meal.
  • Drug should be taken with plenty of fluids to reduce the risk of esophageal irritation or ulceration.
  • Patient should avoid iron-containing preparations or antacids containing aluminum, calcium, or magnesium, as concomitant use may impair absorption demeclocycline.
